III* TELEVISION MONITORING STUDIES
From 1951 to 1954 the NAEB received from the FAE grants totalling
$53,000 for conducting six monitoring studies of commercial television pro¬
gramming in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, In addition, a seventh
study was made in New Haven, Connecticut, underwritten by the National
Council of Churches of Christ Communications Research Project.
These monitoring studies (listed in Appendix 4), the only ones of this
magnitude ever attempted, have been useful in identifying trends in commer¬
cial television broadcasting and provide a basis for more intelligent program
planning than was previously available by educational and commercial broad¬
casters alike. They are the only authoritative bench-mark studies known, of
the introduction of a new medium into a culture and social system, in the
first nation to use television on a mass scale. In this capacity they have
enjoyed world-wide circulation and influence.
The results of the first of these studies, even prior to final publica¬
tion, constituted a significant part of the testimony presented before the FCC.
